Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The roles of demography, genetics, and stochasticity in colonization
Award.AbstractNarration:
An important problem in ecology is understanding the factors that enable (or prevent) the successful founding of new populations. Scientists know that two key factors are the numbers of individuals in the founding group (its demography) and the genetic composition of those individuals. A question that has received surprisingly little attention to date, however, is the relative importance of demography and genetics, and how they might interact. The primary reason for this neglect is that populations comprised of more individuals typically harbor more genetic variation, making it difficult to separate the two causes. The study to be carried out will pair a biological model (flour beetles, Tribolium castaneum) with mathematical and statistical models to understand the role of stochasticity (chance) and disentangle the relative contributions of the size and genetics of a founding group as it initiates a new population and spreads in a novel environment.

The research findings will benefit society in multiple ways. They will be relevant to conservation efforts aimed at improving the designs of management plans to reintroduce a species to the wild (such as was done with the California condor). The results will also advance understanding and management of biological invasions, which occur when a species from one area is inadvertently introduced into a new region, and subsequently proliferates to economically and environmentally damaging levels. The study's conclusions will thus enable both policy makers and managers to make better-informed decisions. Additionally, the laboratory experiments to be conducted are of a scale that makes them ideal for involving undergraduates in research, providing excellent, hands-on learning opportunities. Further, graduate students in experimental and mathematical biology will receive training through this project. They will work directly with the senior scientists and with one another, gaining skills not only as scientists, but also learning to communicate and collaborate with individuals outside their specialized fields. Wide dissemination of the study's results will spread them well beyond traditional expert audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

The number of individuals founding a new population, and their genetic composition, largely determine whether the population will successfully establish or will go extinct. We evaluated the roles of demography (with a focus on numbers of individuals and random fluctuations in births and deaths and in sex ratio) and genetic background (more or less variation) in the colonization process, from population founding through to subsequent growth, and further spread.  We used flour beetles from the genus Tribolium as our biological model system to conduct experiments in the laboratory, and paired them with quantitative mathematical models to disentangle the relative influences of numbers of individuals and their genetic background.


Colonization success increased with the number of individuals and the genetic diversity of the founding group. Number of individuals was only crucial when populations were very small. Genetic diversity had immediate impacts, as well as long term consequences for adaptation. In general, while both were important, the effects of genetic background were more potent than the effects of demography.


Our research is relevant to biological invasions and range expansion (e.g. in the context of human altered environments). We found that evolution across an expanding front could speed the rate at which a population colonizes new habitat and expands its range, as well as making colonization less predictable. Furthermore, adaptation to a novel habitat increases expansion speed as well, just by increasing population sizes, and thus movement of individuals away from crowded areas.


Broader impacts

The completed work is extremely pertinent to biological invasions and to restoration and conservation efforts, and thus will benefit society by aiding in management decisions. Having sufficient genetic variation to adapt may trump preserving genetically distinct populations, if those populations are at risk of imminent extinction. This work should also spur new models for the prediction of spatial spread of invasive species or range shifts induced by climate change. New models that include spatial evolutionary processes will provide substantial gains in their predictive accuracy and estimates of uncertainty.


More than 20 undergraduates received training as part of this project, with 5 of them involved in the full scientific process from experimental design through data collection and analysis to publication of our findings. Three graduate students and three postdoctoral fellows were also involved, and all received mentoring and gained valuable professional skills through this project.


Our results have reached audiences beyond scientists through the mainstream media, through school outreach, and public lectures.
